1.26.19  9:10 pm   Bit of a rant, I'm looking for any advice. I'm in high school and I've been having a really bad year. My grades are great and I have plenty of friends, but I feel terrible. My life is pretty good, but... I don't really have hobbies or personal projects that I do. It makes me feel super unaccomplished.

All I'm acheiving are some numbers in a grade book for some distant promise that I can use them to get a decent job. That's it, that's my life. I study and I get good grades. It frustrates me to no end. I want something unique to me! I'm not going to be in high school forever, and I want something to carry with me to college and beyond.

What I'm asking is if you have struggled with similar things, and how you overcame them. Or if you haven't, since you seem to have been passionate about music from day 1, how can I start working on me? It's a big big world and I don't even know where to start!

html: 1.25.19  8:20 pm   When it comes to thinking about hiring help are you in need of help more for videos or for music? Because I would think you'd want to leave the music 100% in your control but get editors to speed up the video making (which i seem to remember you saying take longer to do than music). In that case you would be like a movie director directing the editor. But also the master because any editor you hire would have to go through an apprenticeship to understand your methods. Also, it would finally be a good time for you to update your software because the editor would be using the new software so he would teach you about it while you tutor him on your process. But I guess you'd certainly need more money to be abel to also pay the editor. All in all it could be cool. Do you agree with my assessment or were you thinking something different?

html: 1.25.19  6:59 pm   Hey, i'm just now learning about intervals and harmonies and stuff and i've been listening to this song and it just confused me. (https://youtu.be/GC6nSX67Q-4?t=31 i linked to the relevant part at 31 sec). Listen to the guitar melody, it has these notes in it, ignoring all the little thrills and slides, - F# B A C#. And then the second guitar comes in and harmonizes over the first and I figured out that the harmony is a minor third (correct me if im wrong). But here's the confusion: the notes in the harmony are A D C# E, and A D E are all a minor third of the corresponding notes in guitar 1 - F# B C#. BUT the C# in guitar 2 is a MAJOR THIRD away from the A in guitar 1. And it sounds bloody cool. What's going on here, why isn't that C# a C, and why does changing that one note make it sound so much better?
